Award.AwardTitle: Virginia Operator Theory and Complex Analysis Meeting (VOTCAM)
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides three years of funding to help defray the expenses of participants in the "Virginia Operator Theory and Complex Analysis Meeting," a conference series in which the 2014 event will take place on November 8, 2014, on the campus of Washington and Lee University.

The Virginia Operator Theory and Complex Analysis Meeting (VOTCAM) is an annual regional conference that has taken place since 1992. It brings together a diverse group of mathematicians whose primary research interest is in function theoretic operator theory and related areas. A sampling of the topical foci of the 2014 event is given by the following: operator theory and complex analysis, operator theory and mathematical physics, operator algebras. The conference program provides ample opportunity for graduate students, postdocs, and other young scientists to present their work.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award helped support speakers and participants at the Virginia Operator Theory and Complex Analysis Meeting (VOTCAM) during the years 2014, 2015 and 2016. VOTCAM is a one-day annual meeting of analysts mainly specializing in Complex Analysis, Operator Algebras, and Functional Analysis. Each year we hosted around 40 participants and either five or six speakers representing different areas of analysis in different stages in their careers.

In 2014, VOTCAM hosted six speakers including two postdocs and two assistant professors. Each speaker gave either at 30 or 50-minute talk. The talks covered topics from Banach space theory (Ryan Causey) to the Dynamics of Representation Theory (Kostya Medynets). Other speakers were Chris Ramsey (UVa), Stefan Garcia (Pomona), Kelly Bickel (Bucknell), Mike Jury (University of Florida).

In 2015 we had a keynote speaker Nate Brown (PSU) give two lectures on a recent breakthrough in nuclear C*-algebras. Also in 2015, we were able to host two international speakers Isabelle Chalendar (Bordeaux-France) and Niels Laustsen (Lancaster-UK) who each delivered 50-minute lectures. Other speakers included Matt Ziemke (University of South Carolina) and Brett Wick (Wash. U)

In 2016, VOTCAM had three senior speakers and three junior speakers who gave 50 minute and 30-minute talks, respectively. In Banach space theory we had a fantastic talk by Bill Johnson (TAMU). We also had two excellent talks from junior people in Operator Algebras: Ben Hayes (now at UVa) and Isaac Goldbring. In 2016 VOTCAM was hosted by the University of Richmond. Other speakers included Tomek Kania (Warwick), Irina Holmes (Wash. U) and Stefan Richter (U. Tenn).

Each event had more than 40 participants including senior researcher, undergraduates, graduate students, and postdocs from regional universities. When funds were available, we supported participants by reimbursing them for lodging. Additional funds to pay for lunch, coffee, tea and light breakfast were provided by Washington and Lee University Office of the Provost.  

The intellectual merit in holding these meetings is in the dissemination of results and ideas to be presented.

The broader impact of meetings was in establishing a forum where researchers and graduate students can come together in an intimate setting to share ideas and establish research contacts. Conferences like this allow people from a variety of different areas of analysis—from traditional operator theory, complex analysis and Banach space theory to non-traditional applications such as quantum computing—to learn more about the field outside of their own research areas. 


Last Modified: 08/11/2017
Modified by: Kevin J Beanland
